question: Question_03_(c)
statement:
Full-Solution Problem. Justify your answers and show all your work.
Simplification of answers is not required.

 Evaluate the following integral.

$\int\frac{dx}{\sqrt{x^{2}+2x+5}}$
hints:
The integral of $\sec \theta$ should appear. This was one of the
trickier integrals we did in the course. What was the trick we used?

To evaluate

$\int \sec \theta \, d\theta$

Try multiplying top and bottom by

$\frac{\sec \theta + \tan \theta}{\sec \theta + \tan \theta}.$

Don't forget to plug back to the original variables. You will need to
draw a triangle and figure out what $\sec \theta$ is in terms of
\emph{x}.
